{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3550646,"name":"Nicollas","username":"Nicollas","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/59ef9b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-07T19:58:31.582Z","cooked":"

Hello, our team is currently facing a specific Spark Max error:

ERROR 4 [CAN SPARK] IDs: 10, WPILib or External HAL Error: CAN: Message not found Periodic Status 2

The code contains a constant PID that places our elevator at a desired position. On the first test of the day, it works perfectly with the PID fully functional. However, as the tests proceed, when we turn the robot off and on again, it starts accumulating a certain PID error. Could this Spark error be due to something physical or just a programming issue?

Periodic code:

public void periodic() {
    SmartDashboard.putNumber("Encoder", getElevatorEncoderPosition());
    SmartDashboard.putBoolean("Mode", modeElevator.mode);
    SmartDashboard.putNumber("Current Motor", elevatorLeftMotor.getOutputCurrent());

    SmartDashboard.putNumber("PID", pidController.getP());

    pidController.setTolerance(Constants.ElevatorConstants.PID_TOLERANCE);
    pidController.setSetpoint(stateElevator.position);

    double pidOutput = pidController.calculate(elevatorLeftMotor.getEncoder().getPosition(), stateElevator.position);
    double feedforwardOutput = feedforward.calculate(elevatorLeftMotor.getEncoder().getPosition(), elevatorLeftMotor.getEncoder().getVelocity());
    double speed = pidOutput + feedforwardOutput;

    if (!modeElevator.mode) {
        elevatorLeftMotor.set(speed * Constants.ElevatorConstants.ELEVATOR_SPEED);
    }
}

You’re not using the feedforward class correctly. You should read the parameter descriptions in the javadocs.

Did you follow the steps with the interactive tuning simulation below?

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Tuning a Vertical Elevator with Motion Profiling

In this section, we will tune a simple position controller for a vertical elevator. In addition, we will discuss the advantages of using motion profiling for this situation. About the Profiler: A M...

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-03-07T21:03:35.674Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":31,"readers_count":30,"score":6.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":494664,"topic_slug":"spark-max-error-and-pid-accumulation-in-elevator-system","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/introduction/tuning-elevator.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Tuning a Vertical Elevator with Motion Profiling — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":73398,"username":"Nicollas","name":"Nicollas","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/59ef9b/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/spark-max-error-and-pid-accumulation-in-elevator-system/494664/8","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3550750,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-07T22:08:00.125Z","cooked":"

To highlight the usage error: The FeedForward cannot provide correct results, because you’re not providing it the values it needs. A feed-forward represents a projected output based on knowing what the hardware should be doing. However, with your code as written, you don’t actually know what the moment to moment expected speed and acceleration are. You need a motion profile for that.

So, what you’re doing is actually feeding it wrong data, with wrong units: Instead of the “expected” velocity for that stage of motion, you’re giving it the “current” speed; This effectively acts as an additional P gain; The faster it’s moving, the faster it says to keep moving.
And for the feedforward’s expected acceleration, you’re giving it a position. This is going to result in some really bizarre drift, since you’re telling it to accellerate when it’s high up.

Removing the “feedforward” being added to your output is probably a quick fix, because it’s not being used properly, and intruding output bugs. Similarly, you can run “calculate” with 0 velocity and 0 accel; This is mathematically equivalent just adding the kG value from an elevator feed forward.

Once you implement a motion profile, then you can query the motion profile for what it thinks is the right velocity and accelleration, and properly calculate the feedforward.
